headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: I guess, Steve, Ganesh and Eric, I was wondering if I could get a little bit more detail kind of about what the actions you're taking around utilization rates in your own fabs. I'm kind of curious, do you think September will represent the trough, I guess
componenttext: I guess, Steve, Ganesh and Eric, I was wondering if I could get a little bit more detail kind of about what the actions you're taking around utilization rates in your own fabs. I'm kind of curious, do you think September will represent the trough, I guess Steve, given your comments about uncertainty around December but possibly a scenario with December is a little bit better than normal seasonal week. Does that mean that most of the utilization action is behind you or how should I think about that? And Eric, remind me again how that flows through the gross margin.

headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, let me comment on the utilization. First of all, the factory in Oregon is a newer factory and in a newer factory, once every 5 years, we need a major shutdown to repair things that can be repaired while the factory is running. And that shutdown has
componenttext: Well, let me comment on the utilization. First of all, the factory in Oregon is a newer factory and in a newer factory, once every 5 years, we need a major shutdown to repair things that can be repaired while the factory is running. And that shutdown has been previously scheduled for a year for this October. And that shutdown usually is about 7 to 8 days. We have to shut the factory and we reserve for it going into that shutdown and it's a plant shutdown, we have to do it once every 5 years. We are currently planning to tuck on a few more days to it to get inventory down because the factory will be shutdown anyway. Rather than starting and stopping, it will be best to extend that a little bit. And the factory in Tempe is a much older facility and doesn't have as many redundancies built into it. And the Tempe facility [indiscernible], we always do that and December and over the holidays. So this time again, we'll have a is shutdown in Tempe facility over the holidays and we're planning to tuck on a few more days do that to correct the inventory. So you will see our internal inventory rise in the September quarter, but than it corrects because we've got shutdowns in both factories in the December quarter. The normal shutdown, we accrue it over 4 quarters and the balance over the year but the extra shutdown days, we're going to do -- will charge of the current quarter, basically, in the quarter which happens which will be the calendar Q4. So Q4 gross margin would be impacted, I don't know whether Eric [indiscernible] the dollar at this point in time it will be GAAP or non-GAAP, it will be a 1 have phenomena.

headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think Steve, you've answered John's question. And at this point in time, we're not willing to give guidance for December quarter gross margin. So we'll leave it at that.
componenttext: Yes, I think Steve, you've answered John's question. And at this point in time, we're not willing to give guidance for December quarter gross margin. So we'll leave it at that.

headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's helpful, guys. Maybe my follow-up for Steve and Ganesh. Steve and Ganesh, we tend to like to sometimes compare apples-to-oranges in Wall Street and when you look at your microcontroller business and oftentimes you compare it that don't have sort of
componenttext: That's helpful, guys. Maybe my follow-up for Steve and Ganesh. Steve and Ganesh, we tend to like to sometimes compare apples-to-oranges in Wall Street and when you look at your microcontroller business and oftentimes you compare it that don't have sort of the 8-bit part of the business and might be relatively new entrant. And then I guess, I'm trying to think about kind of your relative growth rate in microcontrollers versus your peers. Is the right way for us to think about this is given your breadth [ph] of 8-bit perhaps you're more cyclical in these parts of the cycle. And if that's the case, maybe Ganesh, you can give us some metrics around 16- and 32-bit that make you guys comfortable that you're at least maintaining, if not gaining, share in those segments of the market?

headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: So we don't breakout 16- and 32-bit as you may recall from about 2 or 3 quarters ago. But we did present in April where market share results were and we had significant growth in market share in each of 8-, 16- and 32-bit. So we look at the market as a co
componenttext: So we don't breakout 16- and 32-bit as you may recall from about 2 or 3 quarters ago. But we did present in April where market share results were and we had significant growth in market share in each of 8-, 16- and 32-bit. So we look at the market as a continuum of solutions that are needed. In many creases, an 8-bit is good enough. In some cases, it's a 16-bit and in other cases, it's 32-bit. And we see growth opportunities in all 3 of them, both in terms of the applications and the markets that they can go into. So our view is that there is growth that is taking place and there growth relatively had in all 3 segments. We're not looking at 8-bit to save us a 32-bit to save us or 16-bit to save us. All 3 of them, we expect will grow.

headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015

headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: The first question is on Micrel and you talked about $0.25 accretion over 1 or 2 years. Could you give us some help in determining how much of that perhaps we might see a bit earlier and how much of that would have to wait? Your comments said that much of
componenttext: The first question is on Micrel and you talked about $0.25 accretion over 1 or 2 years. Could you give us some help in determining how much of that perhaps we might see a bit earlier and how much of that would have to wait? Your comments said that much of this or I guess majority of this comes from the fab closure. And I'd assume that that is something we have to wait for a little bit. But perhaps, there are some near-term accretion as you start to control some of the OpEx?

headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So there is near-term accretion. I don't know if I have a breakdown considering we're closing the acquisition just today. Before that, all we have some model us and we have quickly verified some stuff. But if you give us a little more time, maybe as
componenttext: Yes. So there is near-term accretion. I don't know if I have a breakdown considering we're closing the acquisition just today. Before that, all we have some model us and we have quickly verified some stuff. But if you give us a little more time, maybe as we get on the road and see that some conferences or the next conference call, we can have much more intelligent numbers for you. But there is accretion coming from expense reduction and other things prior to that. It's not all from fab.

headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just with the kind of a follow-up on the market conditions as well, and I'm sure you've heard from some others. There was, I guess there were some different commentary regarding the pace of bookings through the quarter kind of how things have st
componenttext: Okay. And just with the kind of a follow-up on the market conditions as well, and I'm sure you've heard from some others. There was, I guess there were some different commentary regarding the pace of bookings through the quarter kind of how things have started in the month for the quarter or the month of July. I wonder if you could give some clarity on that linearity from the June quarter, how July has gotten started and if that's giving you some incremental optimism or pessimism as you look forward?

headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think, I listen to some of the call and it's amazing how the customers in placing bookings are kind of behaving almost the same for everybody. And I could say the same thing that this quarter's bookings look better than it was last quarter. There was so
componenttext: I think, I listen to some of the call and it's amazing how the customers in placing bookings are kind of behaving almost the same for everybody. And I could say the same thing that this quarter's bookings look better than it was last quarter. There was some strength in the overall numbers. But that's baked into the guidance. And I think if you look at various peoples commentary last quarter, April was good and May was good and then June fell off. I think people make these adjustments to the quarter and a better July doesn't necessarily mean a better end of September for us and anybody else because customers can correct that any time in the quarter. Sometimes if you place bookings earlier, so whatever product they need for the quarter, they have commitment from the supplier that they will get the product for their needs. And it is easy for them to cancel or slip it out that I only need it in September, give it to me in October then to have a situation where they don't place order and September quarter comes, they need something and somebody's lead time is more than 40 weeks and they can't get it. So customers simply have very little penalty for getting their queue in line, almost no penalty. So therefore, it's not unusual for the first quarter some time to see stronger bookings only to get corrected later on. And I would not read so much into it for anybody.

headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] We'll move to Kevin Cassidy with Stifel.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] We'll move to Kevin Cassidy with Stifel.

headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Going back to the Micrel fab and shutting that down, you gave data points that 5 products have moved. Can you say what is the determination between getting it close in 1 year to 2 years. Is it customer qualification or of finding other fabs that can manuf
componenttext: Going back to the Micrel fab and shutting that down, you gave data points that 5 products have moved. Can you say what is the determination between getting it close in 1 year to 2 years. Is it customer qualification or of finding other fabs that can manufacture?

headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's a good question. So we bought Supertex on April 1, 2014, and we closed the Supertex fab in April of 2015. It took us about 13 months. And that fab was much smaller than Micrel fab. Micrel fab is a larger company than Supertex. But we learned a lot
componenttext: That's a good question. So we bought Supertex on April 1, 2014, and we closed the Supertex fab in April of 2015. It took us about 13 months. And that fab was much smaller than Micrel fab. Micrel fab is a larger company than Supertex. But we learned a lot doing Supertex and we were able to do that in 13 months. And we're a much larger team and we're going to transfer the products that's more than twice the rate and actually would transfer the products from Supertex fab into. And the basic difference between whether it's a year or 2 years is sometimes the customers, the product from the new fab, products coming out of fab and working first time and it is traded. Running into any kind of equipment issues, equipments and fab seems to be different. We believe we can emulate Micrel's process on our equipment, and we have successful in the first couple of processes we are attempting so far. But at any point in time, you can run into a challenge and have to then convert a Micrel piece of equipment from 6-inch or 8-inch and buy a new 1 and have 3, 4, 5 month delay in getting that equipment. So there's a lot of unknowns, a lot of unknowns. That's why we gave this band 1 year or 2 years. My desire is 11 months, but I don't get everything I desire. I think it's going to be somewhere between 1 to 2 years.

headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, maybe just -- maybe it's unknown also, but is there a chance that there will be some products that you can't manufacture somewhere else and it will be discontinued or maybe not get the full revenue that Micrel had?
componenttext: Okay, maybe just -- maybe it's unknown also, but is there a chance that there will be some products that you can't manufacture somewhere else and it will be discontinued or maybe not get the full revenue that Micrel had?

headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, no. So what we do is there's always come especially in analog, there's a lot of products that need 1 fab in 1 or every 2 years. And those products don't make sense to masked set to put a cost and transferring it. So usually on those masked set, ther
componenttext: Well, no. So what we do is there's always come especially in analog, there's a lot of products that need 1 fab in 1 or every 2 years. And those products don't make sense to masked set to put a cost and transferring it. So usually on those masked set, there are strategic inventory of 4 years or so. So if the product means 1 run a year and your run 4 runs out of the Micrel fab before you shut it down, now you have 4 years of customer demand. Then you're 4 years to figure it out, what are going to do with it. It's going to us or take it to a subcontractor, transfer the equipment, do whatever. So that's what we will do. That's not going to hold up the fab. and Micrel is a small company as a percentage of Microchip's. So even though there will be a strategic transition inventory built on the products were transferring and the product that we are not transferring, the products we are transferring, you how to build some strategic inventory on those 2 because you got to give because number time to qualify 8-inch material while they have 6-inch material available. So you will see that strategic inventory build on our balance sheet. But it's not going to be that large compared to the size of the company and its strategic in nature.

headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015

componenttext: We'll move next to Gilbert Alexandre with Associates.

headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015

componenttext: I guess, maybe just one quick on what you're seeing and in the terms of your guidance. headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015

componenttext: I don't know if I can decipher anymore, Chris. I mean, our business in September quarter, based on guidance, is worse than last quarter and so is everybody else's. So for the guidance I think but again is for September is worse than what we accomplished in June. So they've got a little bit spread then bookings progress on this but in bookings and also in July, my assessment is that customers trying to lock up their place in line for September, not any indifferent by for us versus anybody else. So I really wouldn't read anything more than that.

componenttext: Okay, great. And then my follow-up is just to follow up things for Micrel. Is there any way that you can follow the benefit from shutting down their fab? And in the December quarter, would sort of revenue should we assume from Micrel because I believe you guys drove an incorporating 2 quarters [indiscernible] 2 months of it in this quarter. Anything you could talk about in terms of your plans, OpEx reductions from Micrel in the December quarter as well?

headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think it's first to give that considering the deal closed 2 hours ago. So that's just be a little bit more patient. I think we can then do a better job 2 weeks from now but not today. We are cutting expenses. We are letting number of people go as we're
componenttext: I think it's first to give that considering the deal closed 2 hours ago. So that's just be a little bit more patient. I think we can then do a better job 2 weeks from now but not today. We are cutting expenses. We are letting number of people go as we're merging this divisions and high level of senior leadership that we do not need. So we're making those changes and we got to dollar rises. We are unable to give you December quarter Micrel guidance. Micrel revenue has been falling for 4 years, and recently, has fallen a little harder and we need to understand that. We need to meet with the distributors. We need to see what Microchip sales force can do. So I don't quite trust the guidance that I'm hitting from them. So therefore, I'm not able to give December guidance on it yet.

headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015

headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015

headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Steve, I was wondering if you could maybe elaborate a little further on the China weakness. Specifically, which segments or which verticals are you seeing the weakness, and others have been when you talked about China being weak back in October, you menti
componenttext: Steve, I was wondering if you could maybe elaborate a little further on the China weakness. Specifically, which segments or which verticals are you seeing the weakness, and others have been when you talked about China being weak back in October, you mentioned the industrials vertical. Wondering if that has spread to other verticals within China. Any color there would be helpful.

headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think China is weak across the board, exactly what it was and October. I don't remember my quotation in having industrial in it. I said we believe another industry correction has began. This correction will be seen broadly across the industry in the nea
componenttext: I think China is weak across the board, exactly what it was and October. I don't remember my quotation in having industrial in it. I said we believe another industry correction has began. This correction will be seen broadly across the industry in the near future and it will be held by China. So I'm not sure whether it could be more industrial but not only industrial. It's really not that much different than it was back then. China is weak across the board.

headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: And if you could talk about the competitive landscape in the microcontroller market, you have obviously a big pending merger that will be closing in Q4. That merger, the combined entity, will become one of the largest microcontroller suppliers in the worl
componenttext: And if you could talk about the competitive landscape in the microcontroller market, you have obviously a big pending merger that will be closing in Q4. That merger, the combined entity, will become one of the largest microcontroller suppliers in the world both in the 8-bit and 32-bit side and huge the automotive markets. So I want to get a sense from you how of how you're doing the competitive landscape going forward given these in market share and M&A that's occurring.

headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think if you will scan our history of 25 years, we believe we began with nothing and competing with the some of the largest microcontroller manufacturers in U.S., Europe, Asia and Japan. When we were $100 million microcontroller business, we competed wi
componenttext: I think if you will scan our history of 25 years, we believe we began with nothing and competing with the some of the largest microcontroller manufacturers in U.S., Europe, Asia and Japan. When we were $100 million microcontroller business, we competed with people who had billions, Freescale and NXP and Renesas and others. So I'm not sure scale is necessarily a total advantage. We have one that to disciplined approach, to developing products, to running a very responsible P&L, having a high-margin business. We go to market totally different than other people do. Other people try to seek very large chunks of business that's very, very large OEMs of which are often at lower margin and not sticky and I [indiscernible] 100,000 customers and no single customer is larger than 1.5% of our business. So it's not necessary that our business is always in the same places. And Renesas hasn't been able to stop us in years. Freescale hasn't been able to stop us when they were 100x larger and they're merging with NXP, doesn't really change any for. The data deal closes, I go to work any different than they did before.

headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: And just last question on IoT. Wondering how you're thinking about that market in terms of your competitive position and assembling the building blocks to address the market, and any color in terms of how the intensity of the activity IoT at your customer
componenttext: And just last question on IoT. Wondering how you're thinking about that market in terms of your competitive position and assembling the building blocks to address the market, and any color in terms of how the intensity of the activity IoT at your customer base. Is that really picking up or is it going to take some time to take off.

headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, everybody sees it and people don't kind of break up the numbers and do and everybody's putting different structure to IoT so it's kind of very hard to compare. It's a wild guess. But I will make the claim that we have the strongest IoT franchise. Yo
componenttext: Well, everybody sees it and people don't kind of break up the numbers and do and everybody's putting different structure to IoT so it's kind of very hard to compare. It's a wild guess. But I will make the claim that we have the strongest IoT franchise. You need intelligent microcontrollers, you need RF building blocks. You need WiFi, Bluetooth, Bluetooth Light, RF, ZigBee, we have all of them and you need various ecosystems with software, stacks, middleware and all that. We have all that and we have significant number of cloud partners where you have to think of the often connected equipment or whatever. We have the strongest building blocks of anybody. And we're seeing companies that will take all of their microcontroller business, combine it with sensors or something and partition as on IoT business. Well, you could do that. If the PC is connected to a printer, there is a microcontroller in that chain, that's not really IoT. But it's connected and you can call it IoT. And so I think we gave you a little summary last quarter. Remember...

headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good day, everyone, and welcome to this Microchip Technology First Quarter and Fiscal Year 2016 Financial Results Conference. As a reminder, today's call is being recorded. At this time, I'd like to turn the conference over to Microchip's Chief Financial
componenttext: Good day, everyone, and welcome to this Microchip Technology First Quarter and Fiscal Year 2016 Financial Results Conference. As a reminder, today's call is being recorded. At this time, I'd like to turn the conference over to Microchip's Chief Financial Officer, Mr. Eric Bjornholt. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, everyone. During the course of this conference call, we will be making projections and other forward-looking statements regarding future events or the future financial performance of the company. We wish to caution you that such statements
componenttext:
Good afternoon, everyone. During the course of this conference call, we will be making projections and other forward-looking statements regarding future events or the future financial performance of the company. We wish to caution you that such statements are predictions and that actual events or results may differ materially. We refer you to our press release as of today as well as our recent filings with the SEC that identify important risk factors that may impact Microchip's business and results of operations. 
In attendance with me today are: Steve Sanghi, Microchip's President and CEO; and Ganesh Moorthy, Microchip's COO. I will comment on our first quarter of fiscal 2016 financial performance, and Steve and Ganesh will then give their comments on the results, discuss the current business environment as well as our guidance and provide an update on the acquisition of Micrel, which was completed today. We will then be available to respond to specific investor and analyst questions. 
I want to remind you that we are including information in our press release in this conference call on various GAAP and non-GAAP measures. We have posted a full GAAP to non-GAAP reconciliation on the Investor Relations page of our website at www.microchip.com, which we believe you will find useful when comparing GAAP and non-GAAP results. I will now go through some of the operating results including net sales, gross margin and operating expenses. I will be referring to these results on a non-GAAP basis prior to the effects of acquisition activities and share-based compensation.
Net sales in the June quarter were $534 million, below the mid-point of our guidance, which was $555.5 million, and were up 0.5% from non-GAAP net sales of $531.3 million in the June 2014 quarter. Revenue by product line in the June quarter was $348.2 million for microcontrollers, $127.1 million for analog, $31.8 million for memory, $23.3 million for licensing and $3.7 million of other. Revenue by geography was $104.5 million in the Americas, $114.7 million in Europe and $314.7 million in Asia. I remind you that we recognize revenue based on where we ship our products to, which tends to skew some of the revenue towards Asia, where a lot of contract manufacturing takes place. 
On a non-GAAP basis, gross margins were 58.3% of sales. Non-GAAP operating expenses were 25.6% of sales, below the bottom end of our guidance range. Non-GAAP operating income was 32.6% of sales and net income was $148.9 million. This resulted in $0.69 per diluted share, which while it was at the low end of our guidance, was nonetheless a new record. 
On a GAAP basis, gross margins, including share-based compensation and acquisition-related expenses were 57.9% in the June quarter. GAAP gross margins include the impact of $1.7 million of share-based compensation and $0.5 million in manufacturing shutdown costs associated with the Supertex wafer fab in San Jose. 
Total operating expenses were $187.7 million or 35.2% of sales and include acquisition intangible amortization of $34.6 million, share-based compensation of $12.4 million, $2.2 million of acquisition-related expenses and special charges of $1.6 million. 
GAAP other expense includes a $13.8 million gain on the sale of the remainder of an investment that Microchip acquired as part of the SST acquisition back in 2010 and a $2.2 million gain on the sale of another investment. 
GAAP net income was $130.7 million or $0.60 per diluted share. GAAP net income including -- includes nonrecurring favorable tax events of $18.7 million, which was primarily driven by the release of a deferred tax liability due to some IP ownership restructuring that occurred in the quarter related to our prior acquisition of ISSC. 
In the June quarter, the non-GAAP tax rate was 11.4% and the GAAP tax benefit rate was 9.1%. The GAAP tax rate was favorably impacted by the $18.7 million of nonrecurring tax events that I mentioned before. Our tax rate is impacted by the mix of geographical profits, withholding taxes associated with our licensing business and the tax effect of various nonrecurring items. Excluding any nonrecurring events, we expect our longer-term forward-looking non-GAAP effective tax rate to be about 11% to 12%. 
To summarize the after-tax impact that non-GAAP adjustments had on Microchip's earnings per share in the June quarter, acquisition-related items were about $0.163, share-based compensation was about $0.049, nonrecurring favorable tax events were about $0.086, a favorable difference on the sale of 2 investments during the quarter was about $0.074 and the difference in GAAP and non-GAAP noncontrolling interest at ISSC was a favorable of about $0.002 and noncash interest expense was about $0.035.
The dividend declared today of $0.358 per share will be paid on September 25, 2015, to shareholders of record on September 11, 2015. The cash payment associated with this dividend is expected to be about $75.4 million. This quarter's dividend will be our 52nd consecutive quarter of making a dividend payment. We have never made reductions in our dividend. In fact, this quarter's increase marks the 46th occasion we have increased the dividend payment and our cumulative dividends paid amounts to almost $2.6 billion. This program continues to be an important component of how we return value to our shareholders. 
During that time period that Microchip has paid dividends, we have also purchased back $1.4 billion of our stock. Our combined cash return to shareholders since the inception of our dividend program is almost $4 billion. 
Moving on to the balance sheet. Consolidated inventory at June 30, 2015, was $303.7 million or 123 days, up by 12 days to the levels at the end of the March quarter. Inventory at our distributors was at 37 days and was flat to the March quarter levels. I want to remind you that our distribution revenue throughout the world is recognized on a sell-through basis. We have taken actions to moderate our production activities in our foundry wafer purchases in the current quarter to moderate any inventory build. 
The cash generation in the June quarter, excluding the purchase of the remaining shares of ISSC that were outstanding, our dividend payment, the changes in borrowing levels under the revolving line of credit, was $143.8 million. As of June 30, the consolidated cash and total investment position was $2.43 billion, and our borrowings under our revolving line of credit were $497 million. Excluding dividend payments and our acquisition activities, we expect total cash and investment position to grow by approximately $100 million to $120 million in the September quarter. 
Capital spending was approximately $33.6 million in the June quarter. We expect about $35 million in capital spending in the September quarter and overall capital expenditures for fiscal year 2016 have been reduced from our previously guided $160 million to $125 million. We are selectively adding capital to support the growth of our production capabilities for our fast-growing new products and technologies and to bring in-house more of the assembly and test operations that are currently outsourced. Depreciation expense in the June quarter was $24.7 million. I will now ask Ganesh to give his comments on the performance of the business in the June quarter. Ganesh?

headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Eric, and good afternoon, everyone. Let's take a closer look at the performance of each of our product lines, starting with microcontrollers. Our microcontroller revenue was up 1.3% in the June quarter as compared to the year-ago quarter. We ex
componenttext:
Thank you, Eric, and good afternoon, everyone. Let's take a closer look at the performance of each of our product lines, starting with microcontrollers. Our microcontroller revenue was up 1.3% in the June quarter as compared to the year-ago quarter. We experienced the same broad-based weakness that has been reported by many of our peer group companies. In aggregate, over the last 4 rolling quarters, our microcontroller business was up 8% over the prior 4 rolling quarters. We are continuing to deliver innovative new 8-bit, 16-bit and 32-bit microcontrollers that we believe will enable us to grow faster than the market and gain further market share. Microcontrollers represented 65.2% of Microchip's overall revenue in the June quarter. 
Moving to our analog business, our analog business was down 0.6% in the June quarter as compared to the year-ago quarter. In this business too, we experienced the broad-based weakness that has been reported by many of our peers. In aggregate, over the last 4 rolling quarters, our analog business was up 11% over the prior 4 rolling quarters. Our analog business represented 23.8% of Microchip's overall revenue in the June quarter. We continue to develop and introduce a wide range of innovative and proprietary new products to fuel the future growth of our analog business. 
Our memory business, which is comprised of our Serial E-squared memory products, as well as our SuperFlash Memory products, was down 4.8% in the June quarter as compared to the year-ago quarter. We continue to run our memory business in a disciplined fashion that maintains consistently high profitability, enables our licensing business and sly our microcontroller customers to complete their solutions. Our memory business represented 5.95% of Microchip's overall revenue in the June quarter. 
Now a short update about Micrel and where we are in the integration process. Since the announcement of the acquisition on May 7, we have spent considerable time understanding Micrel's businesses, organization and systems. We have developed detailed integration plans that we have begun to execute today after the transaction closed. As we described in our May 7 conference call, Micrel has 3 product line business units and a small foundry services business. Micrel's linear and power solutions business is a classic highly fragmented analog business. This business, together with Microchip's standard analog business, will form a strong combined portfolio that will serve a broader base of applications and customers and enable a number of cross-selling opportunities. 
Micrel's LAN solutions business consists of a range of Ethernet products, including controllers, switches and physical layers for different speeds. This business will strengthen Microchip's overall Ethernet offering and also enable us to serve a broader set of applications and customers. Micrel's timing solutions business consists of a comprehensive clock and timing portfolio, including frequency control products, clock generation products and clock distribution products. It also includes MEMS technology capability that enables much smaller timing components. This is a brand new field of play for Microchip that we're excited about and see sales synergies with our existing product lines. It also gives us visibility into a range of applications and customers that are new to Microchip, who could be customers for our microcontroller, analog and memory products. 
In regards to sales and field applications, we are planning to keep Micrel's sales and applications engineers, and will cross-train them as well as our existing sales force so that we can find revenue synergies through cross-selling opportunities. We also plan to combine the distribution networks of the 2 companies. Some of the distributors for the 2 companies are the same, while others are different, and our goal is to achieve expanded distribution capabilities for the products of both companies. In regards to manufacturing, Steve will comment in more detail in his section, along with how we expect to see the accretion results rolling out over time. With that, let me now pass it to Steve for some general comments about our business, the Micrel acquisition as well as the guidance going forward. Steve?

headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Ganesh, and good afternoon, everyone. Today, I would like to first comment on the results of the fiscal first quarter of 2016 and then provide guidance for the fiscal second quarter of 2016, including comments on the integration plan for Micrel
componenttext:
Thank you, Ganesh, and good afternoon, everyone. Today, I would like to first comment on the results of the fiscal first quarter of 2016 and then provide guidance for the fiscal second quarter of 2016, including comments on the integration plan for Micrel.
Our June quarter results were shy of our guidance, but were consistent with what others in the semiconductor industry have reported. The quarter started out well, but the negative effects of a very weak economy in China and challenges in Europe led by a very weak euro caused us to finish the quarter below our guidance in revenue. We were able to keep the non-GAAP gross margin percentage and earnings per share within the guidance, albeit on the low end of it. Gross margin of 58.3%, operating expense of 25.6% and operating profit of 32.6% were all very respectable achievements. The June quarter was also our 99th consecutive profitable quarter. I want to thank all the employees of Microchip for their contribution in this remarkable achievement of 99 consecutive profitable quarters. I look forward to the current quarter being 100th consecutive profitable quarter, an achievement unmatched in our industry. 
I will now provide guidance for the September quarter, including Micrel revenue. Our guidance is based on the assumption that Europe will continue to be in the doldrums, and is made worse so by the summer holidays. And China, which has been the engine of growth in the past, remaining slow. In preparing our guidance, we have done bottoms up analysis region by region, distributor by distributor and by major customers. We have also included Micrel revenue from today, August 3, to the end of the quarter as we understand it. 
We expect our net sales in the September quarter to be between $532 million to $569 million and $35 million revenue from the sales of Micrel products from today until the end of the quarter. Without counting Micrel, we expect our net sales to be between flat to down 7% sequentially. I want to remind you that the guidance we are providing is for non-GAAP revenue, which will include sell-through from the distributors of Micrel. The GAAP revenue will be much lower since GAAP does not account for products sold to distributors that were shipped prior to the acquisition effective date. We expect non-GAAP gross margin to be between 57.6% to 57.8% for the combined company, negatively impacted by the lower gross margin of Micrel and sequentially flat without Micrel. We expect the non-GAAP operating expenses to be about 27.7% to 28.9% of sales for the combined company, and we expect the combined company non-GAAP operating profit to be between 28.7% to 30.1% of sales, again negatively impacted by higher expenses and lower operating profit of Micrel. We expect non-GAAP earnings per share to be between $0.58 to $0.66 per share. The non-GAAP earnings per share are impacted by $0.015 dilution coming from the consolidation of Micrel. Now let me provide you more updates on the Micrel acquisition. We closed the acquisition today, and we now begin the hard work of integration to drive shareholder value. The shareholders of Micrel overwhelmingly approved the merger with 98.95% of the Micrel shares that worked in the favor of the merger. As part of the transaction, we will pay an aggregate of approximately $430 million in cash and issue an aggregate of 8,626,795 shares, taking into consideration the equity awards assumed and the cash and investments on Micrel's balance sheet at the closing date. The total enterprise value is in line with the $744 million that we shared with investors when we announced the signing of the definitive agreement back on May 7, 2015. 
Now Ganesh has already covered some of the elements of our integration planning, I will cover 4 areas: First, I will explain to you how the revenue of Micrel will be consolidated into Microchip's SEC revenue reporting; second, I will explain our plans in the IT systems and manufacturing area; third, I will give you guidance on the accretion we expect to get from this acquisition; and finally, I will provide guidance for the long-term financial model for Micrel. 
So let us begin with how the revenue of Micrel will be included in the Microchip's revenue reporting. Micrel breaks down its revenue into 3 reported product lines: Linear and powers solutions, LAN solutions and TCG, which is timing and communication. 99% of Micrel revenue will be reported as analog revenue within Microchip. Approximately 1% of Micrel revenue is on products that are built on a microcontroller core. They're, in fact, special-purpose microcontrollers and will be reported within our microcontroller revenue. 
Now I will give you an update on our integration planning in the IT systems area and in the manufacturing area. In the last 3 months, we have studied the business systems of both companies. Micrel is a small company and its business systems are relatively old. We have laid out a plan that will transfer all of Micrel to Microchip's business systems. We estimate that this transition will be completed sometime in the calendar first quarter of 2016. 
Regarding manufacturing, Micrel operates a small 6-inch fab in San Jose that is about 30% utilized at the current time. Micrel also uses outside foundries for some of its products, mostly for the LAN solutions group. This happened to be some of the same foundries that Microchip uses for some of our products that are outsourced. We will leave those products running in the outside fabs. Our focus will be to deal with 6-inch San Jose fab that is severely underutilized. Microchip will transfer all of Micrel's products from its 6-inch fab to other facilities. A majority of these products will transfer to Microchip's two 8-inch fabs, one in Tempe, Arizona and the second in Gresham, Oregon. Some products may be transferred to other outside foundries wherever there is a better process technology match. We believe that this transfer of all the products from Micrel fab to either Microchip fabs or to some foundries will take about 1 to 2 years. After that, San Jose's 6-inch fab will be closed. 
Regarding back-end manufacturing, Micrel subcontracts 100% of its assembly and test. Many of the packages that Micrel uses are different than Microchip's, but many are the same. Where appropriate, we will apply our expanded purchasing power to lower our supply chain costs. As in the other acquisitions, we will also do a careful make versus buy analysis on each package and product type. Over time, some of the products and packages may be brought into our assembly and test facility while others will remain at the subcontractors. Microchip will, however, combine the manufacturing systems like wafer ordering, assembly and test management, shipments and warehouses. We expect that all Micrel products will be shipping from Microchip's manufacturing systems by the end of the first calendar quarter of 2016. 
With this, let me now provide guidance for accretion from the acquisition of Micrel. We currently expect the Micrel acquisition to be $0.015 dilutive to a non-GAAP EPS for the partial September quarter. The acquisition just closed today, so we need more time to study and provide you further guidance. But with the rate at which we expect the integration to progress, our initial estimate will be that Micrel acquisition will be breakeven throughout December quarter non-GAAP EPS. For longer term, after we have closed the San Jose fab, which is about 1 to 2 years from now, we expect Micrel to add about $0.25 of accretion to Microchip's yearly non-GAAP EPS. These numbers are preliminary and depend upon the speed of integration efforts and the health of the underlying economy in general. 
Finally, let me provide guidance for the long-term financial model for Micrel. Our track record has shown that Microchip has been able to improve the business model of its acquisitions, and our combined business model has remained virtually unchanged. 
If, that after San Jose fab is closed and the oldest 6-inch inventory have been depleted, we will improve the financial model of Micrel to be equivalent to that of Microchip. Given all the complications of accounting for the acquisitions, including amortization of intangibles, restructuring charges and inventory write-up, Microchip will continue to provide guidance and track its results. On a non-GAAP basis, we believe that non-GAAP results provide more meaningful comparison to prior quarters, and we request that the analysts continue to report the non-GAAP estimates in the first call. With this, operator, will you please poll for questions?

headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] We'll take our first question from Craig Hettenbach with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] We'll take our first question from Craig Hettenbach with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Starting first with just industry questions, Steve. If I look at the current environment today, what's your sense, the biggest difference between today versus last fall, when there was also at that time, albeit a brief correction?
componenttext: Starting first with just industry questions, Steve. If I look at the current environment today, what's your sense, the biggest difference between today versus last fall, when there was also at that time, albeit a brief correction?

headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Right, Craig, I was hoping that this question could wait some time at least later, but that's the first question, so let's take it. As the earnings season has progressed, a number of investors and analysts have commented and have asked me how I thought ab
componenttext: Right, Craig, I was hoping that this question could wait some time at least later, but that's the first question, so let's take it. As the earnings season has progressed, a number of investors and analysts have commented and have asked me how I thought about the current environment in the semiconductor, and if this is something that started in October of last year with our earnings volume at that time. I have not engaged into any conversation with any of the investors and analysts because we were in the quiet time. And I thought if the question was asked, I'll address it here. So here it is, that's really the first question. While it's really painful to visit that period again, we do believe that the first signs of a slowdown in China were visible at that time. We saw that through thousands of small customers who were experiencing economic headwinds, and not buying enough products. This was further enhanced by a very tight credit environment that was what prevalent at that time in China. Then after, a warning, the December quarter numbers for most semiconductor companies were incurred by an average of about 5%. The companies in the supply chain of 1 mobile customer were a notable exception. Then came the March quarter which was seasonally weak for most companies due to Chinese New Year, and also some others blamed it on euro weakness which was indeed a new phenomena. So then came in the June quarter which is traditionally a very strong quarter in China, and we saw a broad-based miss from the industry led by China. And the September quarter guidance has been very weak, also driven by China. Now we have semiconductor companies admitting that there was indeed inventory build in China, and that the distribution that needs to correct. We knew from the companies that we have acquired, and others that we conducted diligence on but did not acquire, that there was a broad-based selling driven inventory build in distribution channel, which the prevailing rate of demand could not support. You can only play a selling game for so long. And this time, it cannot truly, went a bit longer. But now everyone's numbers have been cut significantly. A large number of companies are now selling well below the stock prices on October 9 prior to our call. When I said, and I quote, "We believe that another industry correction has begun, and that this correction will be seen more broadly across the industry in the near future." It probably took a quarter longer than it has taken historically, likely masked by the smartphone supply chain, with everyone having some exposure to it. But really, an answer to investor and analyst question, I suggest this is pretty much a continuation of the phenomenon that we saw last October.

headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got it. Just a quick follow-up to that before I have an additional question. If -- the comment on China remains slow. How would you kind of frame, just the environment in China? Do you think we're through most of the inventory correction, and then it'll t
componenttext: Got it. Just a quick follow-up to that before I have an additional question. If -- the comment on China remains slow. How would you kind of frame, just the environment in China? Do you think we're through most of the inventory correction, and then it'll track to demand or any additional thoughts on China for Q3?

headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: We are not through all the inventory correction, no. There will again be differences in sell-in versus sell-through. Also, all of our revenue is sell-through. But we bought Micrel today which had a mixture of sell-in and sell-through with most of China be
componenttext: We are not through all the inventory correction, no. There will again be differences in sell-in versus sell-through. Also, all of our revenue is sell-through. But we bought Micrel today which had a mixture of sell-in and sell-through with most of China being sell-in, which we'll be converting to sell-through, only recognizing sell-through. But there are a number of moving parts in our business, but the industry still has a lot of inventory in China.

headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then, just a follow-up on Micrel. Appreciate the thoughts in terms of how you expect to transform the business, particularly on manufacturing. On the product side, given that you had a little bit of time and talking to customers, any anecdotes
componenttext: Got it. And then, just a follow-up on Micrel. Appreciate the thoughts in terms of how you expect to transform the business, particularly on manufacturing. On the product side, given that you had a little bit of time and talking to customers, any anecdotes or feedback in terms of their product portfolio, and how you see that kind of best fit within Microchip?

headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, so we have decided to take the Linear and Power Solutions business which was the largest division inside of Micrel, and completely fold that within Microchip, which is happening starting today. So essentially, we have taken our analog business and i
componenttext: Well, so we have decided to take the Linear and Power Solutions business which was the largest division inside of Micrel, and completely fold that within Microchip, which is happening starting today. So essentially, we have taken our analog business and internally in Microchip, split it into 2 portions, one is called the analog power and interface division and second is called the mix signal and linear division, they're both about equal size. And then the entire Micrel Linear and Power business is folding into one of those divisions, to the analog power management business. So we will apply our principles, our metrics of R&D and all that. When I look at R&D as a percentage of sales for analog, Microchip is one of the most efficient in the industry. We don't break out individual R&D, but the amount of R&D we spend to get the margins and revenue and all that, and Micrel is one of the worst, when you look at the numbers. So we have to move this from worst to best, and we have done that with others. We've done that with SST and SMSC and Supertex. And over and over and over, you have seen that. That's what we have to do here. Then, there is a LAN business here, which is about $50 million, $50 million, $60 million, and that also we're going to completely fold that into Microchip's USB and networking division, where our LAN business resides. That, again, will then really benefit from our methodologies, our metrics, our management and everything else. And the third business here is the timing business, which is a new business for us, and we will keep that as a business unit, but it will report into one of our seasoned general managers, so it can also get the mentorship and really move towards that model.

headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015

componenttext: We'll move next to William Stein with SunTrust.

headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015

headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think I resigned from the forecasting business last year. You might recall that in November. I'm not going to make that comment looking forward for the industry. If we just look at ourselves, we think we gave you September quarter guidance already. Dece
componenttext: I think I resigned from the forecasting business last year. You might recall that in November. I'm not going to make that comment looking forward for the industry. If we just look at ourselves, we think we gave you September quarter guidance already. December is personally a weak quarter for Microchip, and also for the industry. Considering this correction happening in June and September, what would manifest for December, it's kind of hard to see right now. But as we go through the quarter, one could make a case that December quarters should not seasonally be weak, because ordinarily, December quarter is followed by a very strong June and September, this time it is not. But I'm not making that prediction today. I'd like to see the quarter. I got to see the booking, the backlog, everything else, and talk about it later, maybe as we go on the road. The biggest leverage here, short term is really improving Micrel's business. And I think there is a fair amount of opportunity for us to do that. And the largest leverage comes from the fab. There is 30% utilization in the fab, and we dramatically lower its cost by transferring product. And the first 5 products will be running at a Microchip fab in about 6 weeks.

headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's great, Steve. I appreciate that. Maybe I can use that as sort of a next question. So after completing this deal and understanding that all the synergies and all the work is still in front of you, I'm wondering if you can characterize the current ap
componenttext: That's great, Steve. I appreciate that. Maybe I can use that as sort of a next question. So after completing this deal and understanding that all the synergies and all the work is still in front of you, I'm wondering if you can characterize the current appetite for future M&A. It certainly helps dull the pain from the current demand environment a little bit. And I'm wondering how much appetite there is for more of that now.

headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, we have substantial line in place, which we did that earlier in February, and we have constantly good number of companies in our funnel that we're constantly talking to, dating with, analyzing and there's no guarantee. These things are not schedulab
componenttext: Well, we have substantial line in place, which we did that earlier in February, and we have constantly good number of companies in our funnel that we're constantly talking to, dating with, analyzing and there's no guarantee. These things are not schedulable at any given point in time. And some time, it takes longer for a deal to materialize. Other times, it's shorter. But yes, we still have appetite for the next acquisition, no question about it.

headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: We'll move next to John Pitzer with Credit Suisse.
componenttext: We'll move next to John Pitzer with Credit Suisse.

headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: I guess, Steve, Ganesh and Eric, I was wondering if I could get a little bit more detail about kind of the actions you're taking around utilization rates in your own fabs. I'm kind of curious, do you think September will represent the trough, I guess Stev
componenttext: I guess, Steve, Ganesh and Eric, I was wondering if I could get a little bit more detail about kind of the actions you're taking around utilization rates in your own fabs. I'm kind of curious, do you think September will represent the trough, I guess Steve, given your comments about uncertainty around December, but possibly a scenario with December is a little bit better than normal seasonal week. Does that mean that most of the utilization action is behind you, or how should I think about that? And Eric, remind me again how that flows through gross margin.

headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, let me comment on the utilization. First of all, the Gresham factory in Oregon is a newer factory, and in a newer factory, we need a, once every 5 years, we need a major shutdown to repair things that can be repaired while the factory's running. And
componenttext: Well, let me comment on the utilization. First of all, the Gresham factory in Oregon is a newer factory, and in a newer factory, we need a, once every 5 years, we need a major shutdown to repair things that can be repaired while the factory's running. And that shutdown has been previously scheduled for a year, for this October. And that shutdown usually is about 7 to 8 days. We have to shut the factory, and we reserve for it going into that shutdown and it's a planned shutdown, we have to do it every once in 5 years. We are currently planning to tack on a few more days to it, to bring the inventory down because the factory will be shutdown anyway. And rather than starting and stopping, it'll be best to extend that a little bit. Then the factory in Tempe is a much older facility, and doesn't have as many redundancies built into it. And the Tempe facility [indiscernible] and then, we always do that in December and over the holidays. So this time again, we'll have a shutdown in Tempe facility over the holidays, and we are planning to tack on a few more days to that, to correct the inventory. So you will see our internal inventory rise in the September quarter, but then it corrects because we've got shutdowns in both factories in the December quarter. The normal shutdown, we accrue it over 4 quarters in our balance over the year, but the extra shutdown days, we're going to do -- will charge it to the current quarter, basically, in the quarter it happens, which will be the calendar Q4. So Q4 gross margin would be impacted, I don't know whether Eric is able to dollar either at this point in time, and whether you do a GAAP or non-GAAP, that would be a one-time phenomena.

headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, no I think, Steve, you've answered John's question. And I don't -- at this point in time, we're not willing to give guidance for December quarter gross margin. So we'll leave it at that.
componenttext: Yes, no I think, Steve, you've answered John's question. And I don't -- at this point in time, we're not willing to give guidance for December quarter gross margin. So we'll leave it at that.

headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's helpful, guys. Then maybe with my follow-up, for Steve and Ganesh. Steve and Ganesh, we tend to like to sometimes compare apples-to-oranges here on Wall Street, and we look at your [indiscernible] to microcontroller business, and oftentimes you com
componenttext: That's helpful, guys. Then maybe with my follow-up, for Steve and Ganesh. Steve and Ganesh, we tend to like to sometimes compare apples-to-oranges here on Wall Street, and we look at your [indiscernible] to microcontroller business, and oftentimes you compare it [indiscernible] that don't have sort of the 8-bit part of the business and might be a relatively new entrant. And then I guess, I'm trying to think about kind of your relative growth rate in microcontrollers versus your peers. Is the right way for us to think about this is, given your breadth in 8-bit, perhaps you're more cyclical in these parts of the cycle. And if that's the case, maybe Ganesh, you can give us some metrics around 16- and 32-bit, that makes you guys comfortable, that you're at least maintaining, if not gaining, share in those segments of the market?

headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: So we don't breakout 16- and 32-bit as you may recall from about 2 or 3 quarters ago. But we did present in April, where market share results were, and we had significant growth in market share in each of 8-, 16- and 32-bit. So we look at the market as a
componenttext: So we don't breakout 16- and 32-bit as you may recall from about 2 or 3 quarters ago. But we did present in April, where market share results were, and we had significant growth in market share in each of 8-, 16- and 32-bit. So we look at the market as a continuum of solutions that are needed. In many creases, an 8-bit is good enough. In some cases, it's a 16-bit and in other cases, it's a 32-bit. And we see growth opportunities in all 3 of them, both in terms of the applications and the markets that they can go into. So our view is that there is growth that is taking place, and there growth yet to be had in all 3 segments. We are not looking at 8-bit to save us, a 32-bit to save us or 16-bit to save us alone. All 3 of them, we expect will grow.

headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: And next we'll take Chris Caso with Susquehanna Financial Group.
componenttext: And next we'll take Chris Caso with Susquehanna Financial Group.

headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: The first question is on Micrel, and you talked about $0.25 accretion over 1 or 2 years. Could you give us some help in determining how much of that perhaps we might see a bit earlier, and how much of that would have to wait? Your comments said that much
componenttext: The first question is on Micrel, and you talked about $0.25 accretion over 1 or 2 years. Could you give us some help in determining how much of that perhaps we might see a bit earlier, and how much of that would have to wait? Your comments said that much of this, or I guess a majority of this comes from the fab closure, and I'd assume that is something we have to wait for a little bit. But perhaps, there is some near-term accretion as you start to control some of the OpEx?

headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. And so there is near-term accretion. I don't know if I have a breakdown considering we are closing the acquisition just today. Before that, all we have is a model, and we have quickly verified some stuff. But if you give us a little more time, maybe
componenttext: Yes. And so there is near-term accretion. I don't know if I have a breakdown considering we are closing the acquisition just today. Before that, all we have is a model, and we have quickly verified some stuff. But if you give us a little more time, maybe as we get on the road, and see you at some conferences, or the next conference call, or -- we can have much more intelligent numbers for you. But there is accretion coming from expense reduction and other things prior to that. It's not all from fab.

headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, and just with, just kind of a follow-up on the market conditions as well, and I'm sure you heard from some others. There was a, I guess there has been some differing commentary regarding the pace of bookings through the quarter, kind of how things h
componenttext: Okay, and just with, just kind of a follow-up on the market conditions as well, and I'm sure you heard from some others. There was a, I guess there has been some differing commentary regarding the pace of bookings through the quarter, kind of how things have started in the month -- the quarter and the month of July. I wonder if you could give some clarity on that, both linearity from the June quarter, how July has gotten started, and if that's giving you some incremental optimism or pessimism as you look forward?

headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think, I listen to some of the calls and it's amazing how the customers in placing bookings are kind of behaving almost the same for everybody. And I could say the same thing, that this quarter's bookings look better than it was last quarter. There was
componenttext: I think, I listen to some of the calls and it's amazing how the customers in placing bookings are kind of behaving almost the same for everybody. And I could say the same thing, that this quarter's bookings look better than it was last quarter. There was some strength in the overall numbers. But that's baked into the guidance. And I think, if you look at various people's commentary last quarter, April was good and May was good and then June fell off. So I think people make these adjustments to the quarter and a better July doesn't necessarily mean a better end of September for us or anybody else, because customers can correct that any time in the quarter. Sometimes people place bookings earlier, so whatever product they need for the quarter, they have commitment from the supplier, that they will get the product for their needs. And then it's easy for them to cancel or slip it out, that I only need it in September, give it to me in October, than to have a situation where they don't place the order, and September quarter comes, they need something and somebody's lead time is more than 4 weeks, and they can't get it. So customers simply have very little penalty for getting their queue in line, almost no penalty. So therefore, it's not unusual for the first quarter some time to see stronger bookings, only to get corrected later on. And I would not read so much into it for anybody.

headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] We'll move to Kevin Cassidy with Stifel.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] We'll move to Kevin Cassidy with Stifel.

headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Going back to the Micrel fab and shutting that down, you gave the data points that you have 5 products have moved. Can you say what is the determination between getting it closed in 1 year to 2 years? Is it customer qualifications or of finding other fabs
componenttext: Going back to the Micrel fab and shutting that down, you gave the data points that you have 5 products have moved. Can you say what is the determination between getting it closed in 1 year to 2 years? Is it customer qualifications or of finding other fabs that can manufacture?

headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: So that's a good question. So we bought Supertex on April 1, 2014, and we closed the Supertex fab in April of 2015. It took us about 13 months. And that fab was much smaller than Micrel fab is. Micrel fab is a larger, it's a company than Supertex. But we
componenttext: So that's a good question. So we bought Supertex on April 1, 2014, and we closed the Supertex fab in April of 2015. It took us about 13 months. And that fab was much smaller than Micrel fab is. Micrel fab is a larger, it's a company than Supertex. But we learned a lot doing Supertex, and we were able to do that in 13 months. So we're mounting a much larger team, and we're going to transfer the products at more than twice the rate, then actually would transfer the products from Supertex fab into. And the basic difference between whether it's a year or 2 years is, sometimes you have customers, the product from the new fab, products coming out of fab and working first time, [indiscernible] traded. Running into any kind of equipment issues, equipments and fab seem to be different. We believe we can emulate Micrel's process on our equipment, and we have, successful in the first couple of processes we are attempting so far. But at any point in time, you can run into a challenge, and have to then convert a Micrel piece of equipment from 6-inch to 8-inch, or buy a new 1 and have 3, 4, 5 months delay in getting that equipment. So there are a lot of unknowns, a lot of unknowns. That's why we gave this band of 1 year to 2 years. My desire is 11 months, but I don't get everything I desire. I think it's going to be somewhere between 1 to 2 years.

headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, and maybe just -- maybe it's an unknown also, but is there a chance that there would be some products that you can't manufacture somewhere else, and yet they'd be discontinued and maybe not get the full revenue Micrel had?
componenttext: Okay, and maybe just -- maybe it's an unknown also, but is there a chance that there would be some products that you can't manufacture somewhere else, and yet they'd be discontinued and maybe not get the full revenue Micrel had?

headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, no. So what we do is, they always, especially in analog, there are lots of products that need 1 fab run every 2 years. And those products don't make sense to even have a masked set, and put the cost transferring it. So usually on those masked sets,
componenttext: Well, no. So what we do is, they always, especially in analog, there are lots of products that need 1 fab run every 2 years. And those products don't make sense to even have a masked set, and put the cost transferring it. So usually on those masked sets, we build strategic inventory of 4 years or so. So if the product needs 1 run a year, then you run 4 runs out of the Micrel fab before you shut it down, now you have 4 years of customer demand. Then you have 4 years to figure it out, what you're going to do with it. I build it and I go out there, we'll take it to a subcontractor, transfer the equipment, do whatever. So that's what we will do. That's not going to hold up the fab. And Micrel is a small company as a percentage of Microchip's. So even though there'll be a strategic transition inventory built on the products we are transferring, and on the product we're not transferring, the products we are transferring, you have to build some strategic inventory on those too, because you've got to give the customer time to qualify 8-inch material, while they have 6-inch material available. So you will see that strategic inventory build on our balance sheet. But it's not going to be that large compared to the size of the company and its strategic in nature.

headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015

headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015

componenttext: I guess, you -- just one quick [indiscernible] on what you're seeing, and in the terms of your guidance. So I think as the other Chris said, some of the competitors are saying that business is getting better. So are you implicit in your guidance, are you assuming that your business is going to get a little worse or just kind of remain at this level throughout the quarter?

headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: I don't know if I can decipher anymore, Chris. I mean, our business in September quarter, based on guidance, is worse than last quarter, and so is everybody else's. So for the guidance I have seen, the guidance for September is worse than what we accompli
componenttext: I don't know if I can decipher anymore, Chris. I mean, our business in September quarter, based on guidance, is worse than last quarter, and so is everybody else's. So for the guidance I have seen, the guidance for September is worse than what we accomplished in June. So they've got a little bit spurt in bookings,  I saw the spurt in bookings, and also in July, my assessment is that customers trying to lock up their place in line for September, not any indifferent by -- for us, versus anybody else. So I really wouldn't read anything more than that.

headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then my follow-up, just a couple of things on Micrel. Is there any way you could quantify the benefit from shutting down their fab? And then, in the December quarter, what sort of revenue should we assume from Micrel, because I believe yo
componenttext: Okay, great. And then my follow-up, just a couple of things on Micrel. Is there any way you could quantify the benefit from shutting down their fab? And then, in the December quarter, what sort of revenue should we assume from Micrel, because I believe you guys drove in, incorporating 2 quarters, or excuse me, 2 months of it in this quarter. And anything you could talk about, in terms of your plans, OpEx reductions from Micrel in the December quarter as well?

headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: So I think it's first to give that considering the deal closed 2 hours ago. Probably just be a little bit more patient. I think I could, we can do a better job 2 weeks from now, but not today. We are cutting expenses. We are letting a number of people go,
componenttext: So I think it's first to give that considering the deal closed 2 hours ago. Probably just be a little bit more patient. I think I could, we can do a better job 2 weeks from now, but not today. We are cutting expenses. We are letting a number of people go, as we are merging these divisions with the high level senior leadership that we do not need. So we're making those changes and we got a dollar rises. We are unable to give you December quarter Micrel guidance. Micrel revenue has been falling for 4 years, and recently, has fallen a little harder and we need to understand that. We need to meet with the distributors. We need to see what Microchip's sales force can do. So I don't quite trust the guidance that I'm hitting from them. So therefore, I'm not able to give December guidance on it yet.

headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's fine. Can you tell us what it was in the June quarter, the revenue for Micrel?
componenttext: That's fine. Can you tell us what it was in the June quarter, the revenue for Micrel?

componenttext: Well, I think the June quarter really wasn't announced because the acquisition closed. And I'm not sure whether I'm in a position to say that.

headline: Microchip Technology Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2015
